Schild, A. Wokaun* Physical Chemistry 11, University of Bayreuth, P.O. Box 101251, D-W-8580 Bayreuth (F. R. G.) and A. Baiker Department of Chemical Engineering and Chemical Technology, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, ETH Zentrum, CH-8092 Zurich (Switzerland) (Received February 18, 1991; revised April 25, 1991) Abstract The mechanism of methane formation over a palladium/zirconia catalyst prepared by wet impregnation of amorphous Zr02 has been investigated by diffuse reflectance FTIR spectroscopy. The production rate of surface formate, which represents the pivotal surface intermediate, is high when starting from gaseous COZ and H2; a considerably lower rate is observed upon hydrogen exposure of a carbonate-covered catalyst surface. Reference compounds have been adsorbed to deternune the C=O stretching frequency of a potential formyl (HCO) surface intermediate, which apparently gives rise to a broad absorption around 1700 cm-'. This band is not observed under COZ hydrogenation conditions. Instead, a characteristic absorption is detected at 1760 cm-', which is assigned to CO triply bound to the palladium particles. The latter species is correlated with surface formate, in an equilibrium that involves surface hydroxyl groups on the zirconia. No further surface species are detected under COZ hydrogenation conditions. A mechanism for the hydrogenation of COZ to methane is proposed that accounts for these observations; the importance of surface hydroxyl groups and anion vacancies on the zirconia surface is emphasized. Introduction Hydrogenation reactions of carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide have attracted continuing attention due to their importance for the synthesis of methanol and other feedstock compounds for the chemical industry [ 1-3 ]. In two of our recent studies [3, 4], we have investigated COZ and CO hydrogenation reactions over palladium/zirconia catalysts. A first catalyst was obtained by in situ activation of amorphous Pdz5Zr,5. Methane, water and smaller amounts of carbon monoxide and methanol as gaseous products were observed under COz hydrogenation conditions; no surface species were detected by in situ diffuse reflectance FrIR spectroscopy. For comparison, a second catalyst containing 5 wt.% palladium was prepared by wet impregnation of crystalline monoclinic zirconia. Subsequently, the precipitate was washed with water and methanol, dried at 393 K and calcined at 573 K. The catalyst sample (Pd/Zr02, 5 wt.% palladium) was prepared by wet impregnation of the amorphous airconia with an aqueous solution of (NHQ)2[PdCl4]. After drying at 393 K, the precursor was calcined and reduced in a flowing H2/N2 mixture at 573 K. Before the FTIR measurements, the catalyst was treated in nitrogen or hydrogen flow at temperatures between 450 and 500 K for several hours to remove surface impurities resulting from storage under atmospheric conditions. Nitrogen (Linde, 99.999%) as the carrier gas, as well as carbon dioxide (Linde, 99.99939'0), carbon monoxide (Linde, 99.997%) and hydrogen (Linde, 99.999%) as reactants were used without further purification. Aqueous solutions of glyoxylic acid (Merck, 50%) and glyoxal (Merck, 40%) served as reference compounds in the adsorption experiments. Both compounds were adsorbed by dropping the respective solutions onto the catalyst sample under atmospheric conditions. Spectra were recorded in diffuse reflectance geometry in a controlled environmental chamber (Spectra-Tech, model 0030-100) equipped with CaF2 windows, which was connected to a gas dosing system. The diffuse reflectance accessory (Spectra-Tech, model 0030-033) was placed in the sample beam of the FTIR instrument (Perkin-Elmer, model 1710). After catalyst re-activation, the background spectrum was recorded at an appropriate temperature in the range to be studied during the following experiment (e.g. at 373 K for a range from 298 to 473 K). A mixture of gaseous reactants with the desired composition was enclosed in the reaction chamber at a total pressure of = 3 X 105 Pa. Surface reactions were monitored by recording temperaturedependent FTIR spectra. Typically, 50 to 250 interferograms at a resolution of 8 cm-I were accumulated. Both formaldehyde and methylate can, however, be clearly observed in our experiments with Pd/Zr02, but only when starting from CO/HZ mixtures, on a hydrogenation pathway that leads to methanol as the product (cf. [31 and Fig. 4). A reaction scheme that could account for all of these observations is presented in Fig. 5. The zirconia support with its surface hydroxyl groups acts as the adsorption site; the palladium particles are important as the source of dissociatively adsorbed hydrogen. The formation of formate accompanied by release of water from a surface hydroxyl group is easily formulated. A subsequent combination reaction of formate and = Zr+ would result in a formyl-like species (formyl bound to support oxygen, which is equivalent to monodentate surface formate). If we invoke a second adjacent hydroxyl group for the next step, a surface-bound dioxomethylene species would be formed. Thus, both formyl and dioxomethylene would represent plausible short-lived intermediates on the reaction path from carbon dioxide to methane. These species have, however, never been observed in our experiments. Upon addition of two molecules of hydrogen, the negatively charged oxygen functional groups are protonated and restored as hydroxyl groups on the surface; the CH2 moiety is reduced and desorbed from the surface as methane (cf. Fig. 5). This mechanism is in agreement with several observations of Jackson and Ekerdt [8], who adsorbed CO/H2 mixtures onto Zr02 supports prepared by precipitation. Presence of water on the surface did not prevent the formation of surface formate. Isotope exchange experiments showed that the oxygen required to produce formate was supplied by lattice oxygen and/ or hydroxyl groups. A dioxomethylene species was also formulated [8]. However, on pure zirconia a route for methanol formation via surface methoxide was proposed, although the authors state that the formate - methoxide transition had not been observed directly. The authors also pointed out that the CO hydrogenation rate was markedly increased when the surface was partially dehydroxylated. The concomitant rise in the activity of the zirconia surface was attributed to the increase in anion vacancy density. Note that the sequence of events described by the scheme of Fig. 5 can be easily reformulated in terms of surface anion vacancies, or coordinatively unsaturated zirconia surface centers. If we replace a surface hydroxyl group, --- Zr-OH, by the corresponding vacancy with a positive charge residing on the zirconium atom, = Zr+, the presence of such a vacancy would provide a preferred adsorption site for the products of the first reduction step, i.e. 355 formate and oxygen-bound surface formyl, respectively. If two adjacent vacancies are available, a dioxomethylene species would be anchored to the support by filling two oxygen-deficient sites. Upon further hydrogenation, the release of methane would leave the surface in a hydroxyl-saturated state, from which anion vacancies are regenerated by the desorption of water. Recently, the presence of anion vacancies has been suggested to explain the higher C02 conversion rates observed over palladium supported on amorphous, substoichiometric zirconia (Zr02 _x), as compared to Pd on crystalline Zr02 [3, 9]. Frost [ 101 has recently proposed that the surface density of anion vacancies is increased close to the interface between the support oxide and the embedded metal particle, by electron transfer through the Schottky barrier. The characteristics of the supported metal would then enter only through its work function. However, a recent study by Shaw et al. [ 11 ] in which CeAg2, CeAgCu and CeCu2 alloys were activated in synthesis gas did not provide support for Frost's proposal, but re-emphasized the importance of copper for methanol synthesis. Thus further experimentation is needed to clarify the role of the anion vacancies in CO hydrogenation. No evidence for the presence of surface formyl species is found in the hydrogenation runs described. This fact is in agreement with the observations of Yates and Cavanagh [ 121, who investigated the interaction of several potential formyl precursors with rhodium supported on alumina. The authors searched for the respective CO stretching mode in the vibration range between 1500 and 1800 cm-1; no spectral evidence of stable chemisorbed HCO was found. From our glyoxal and glyoxylic acid adsorption experiments, HCO would be expected to absorb at = 1700 cm-'. If formyl was formed at an intermediate stage, it is likely to undergo rapid transformation into either adsorbed CO or formate, respectively, according to the equilibria shown in Fig. 6. The 1760 cm-1 band observed in some of our spectra (Figs. 1, 2, 4) must therefore rather be assigned to triply bonded CO. This frequency is unusually low compared to data in the literature [ 13, 141, in which the lowest frequencies of CO triply bound on supported palladium are reported around 1800 cm-1. Stretching frequencies of adsorbed CO in the 1700-1800 cm-1 region have been observed on promoted palladium catalysts, and were ascribed to CO-M+ or Pd-CO- - -Pd" complexes, respectively [15-17]. An even lower frequency, 1660 cm-1, was found by Mazzocchia et al. [18], and assigned to a Rh-CO-Zr'+ complex. The presence of promoters can be excluded. One could propose that the positively charged anion vacancies interact with adsorbed CO molecules and lower the C-O bond order. By analogy with the systems mentioned above, a Pd=CO +Zr--complex may be formulated. The correlation of formate and strongly adsorbed, triply bonded CO is supported by several observations. From the dynamics between surface and gaseous species, it appears that formate is rapidly formed from C02/H2, and adsorbed CO is observed later (Fig. 1). Subsequent methane formation causes a strong decrease in intensity of the formate bands, and finally of the CO (ads) signals. An identical behavior for the formation of adsorbed CO was observed over Ni/zirconia catalysts [191. Furthermore, analogous findings were reported by Bowker et al. [201 with ZnO. The authors found that formate was formed by co-adsorption of COZ and hydrogen, while hydrogen/ carbon monoxide dosing did not result in HCOO-formation on the unpromoted ZnO support. However, these observations differ from the results of He et al. over pure Zr02 [211, who found that formate is generated from CO directly, even without the presence of hydrogen. Finally, the scheme in Fig. 6 represents part of a plausible route for the `basic' reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction previously discussed [6, 221, in which COZ is reduced to CO on a catalyst surface, via the intermediacy of surface formate. In this context, the role of palladium in hydrogenation reactions over Pd/Zr02 can be assessed. On pure Zr02, we have only observed [31 carbonates upon adsorption of either CO/H2 or C02/H2 in the temperature range corresponding to this study. In contrast, rapid formation of surface formate has been observed over Pd/Zr02 from either CO/N2 or C02/H2 at temperatures corresponding to reaction conditions. We therefore propose that CO2 is adsorbed on Zr02, and that molecules adsorbed close to the palladium /zirconia interface are subsequently reduced according to the mechanism shown in Fig. 5. The surface formate produced in this step is, in turn, in equilibrium with CO adsorbed on palladium, according to the reactions shown in Fig. 6. Implications that carbon monoxide might also be formed on a further, independent reaction pathway arise from the results presented in Fig. 2, and from the results with Au/Zr02 catalysts [221. In both cases, increasing CO bands are accompanied by a decrease in surface carbonate coverage. Again, the anion vacancies discussed above need to be taken into account, such that carbonate would react with two vacancies, ---Zr', to carbon monoxide and two oxygenated zirconia sites, --- Zr-O. Baiker Department of Chemical Engineering and Chemical Technology, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, ETH Zentrum, CH-8092 Zurich Switzerland The mechanism of methane formation over a palladium/zirconia catalyst prepared by wet impregnation of amorphous ZrO2 has been investigated by diffuse reflectance FTIR spectroscopy. The production rate of surface formate, which represents the pivotal surface intermediate, is high when starting from gaseous CO2 and H2; a considerably lower rate is observed upon hydrogen exposure of a carbonate-covered catalyst surface. Reference compounds have been adsorbed to determine the CO stretching frequency of a potential formyl (HCO) surface intermediate, which apparently gives rise to a broad absorption around 1700 cm−1. This band is not observed under CO2 hydrogenation conditions. Instead, a characteristic absorption is detected at 1760 cm−1, which is assigned to CO triply bound to the palladium particles. The latter species is correlated with surface formate, in an equilibrium that involves surface hydroxyl groups on the zirconia. No further surface species are detected under CO2 hydrogenation conditions. A mechanism for the hydrogenation Of CO2 to methane is proposed that accounts for these observations; the importance of surface hydroxyl groups and anion vacancies on the zirconia surface is emphasized.
